comment.body: The file `bssl_algorithms.py` seems important for the test flow. Why is it in .gitignore?

I've also added a new CircleCI job for BoringSSL interop-testing. Presently it's not a nightly-only job, but I'll change it to be nightly-only once the PR is approved.

I also haven't added a README for these tests, since I'm considering breaking them out into a separate "interoperability testing" repository once we're done with this release cycle.

+import ossl_algorithms
+import bssl_algorithms

+import pytest
+import sys
+import subprocess
+import time
+import os
+import psutil
+
+@pytest.fixture()
+def sig_default_server_port(server_prog, server_type, test_artifacts_dir, worker_id):
+    # Setup: start server
+    sig_alg = "oqs_sig_default"
+    if server_type == "ossl":
+        helpers.gen_openssl_keys(server_prog, os.path.join('apps', 'openssl.cnf'), sig_alg, test_artifacts_dir, worker_id)
+        command = [server_prog, 's_server',
+                                '-cert', os.path.join(test_artifacts_dir, '{}_{}_srv.crt'.format(worker_id, sig_alg)),
+                                '-key', os.path.join(test_artifacts_dir, '{}_{}_srv.key'.format(worker_id, sig_alg)),
+                                '-tls1_3',
+                                '-quiet',
+                                '-accept', '0']
+    elif server_type == "bssl":
+        command = [server_prog, 'server',
+                                '-accept', '0',
+                                '-sig-alg', sig_alg,
+                                '-loop']
comment.body: How is a BoringSSL server picking up the keys and certificates that OpenSSL is using? Maybe a comment here to explain?

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,121 @@
+import ossl_algorithms
+import bssl_algorithms
+import helpers
+import pytest
+import sys
+import subprocess
+import time
+import os
+import psutil
+
+@pytest.fixture()
+def sig_default_server_port(server_prog, server_type, test_artifacts_dir, worker_id):
+    # Setup: start server
+    sig_alg = "oqs_sig_default"
+    if server_type == "ossl":
+        helpers.gen_openssl_keys(server_prog, os.path.join('apps', 'openssl.cnf'), sig_alg, test_artifacts_dir, worker_id)
+        command = [server_prog, 's_server',
+                                '-cert', os.path.join(test_artifacts_dir, '{}_{}_srv.crt'.format(worker_id, sig_alg)),
+                                '-key', os.path.join(test_artifacts_dir, '{}_{}_srv.key'.format(worker_id, sig_alg)),
+                                '-tls1_3',
+                                '-quiet',
+                                '-accept', '0']
+    elif server_type == "bssl":
+        command = [server_prog, 'server',
+                                '-accept', '0',
+                                '-sig-alg', sig_alg,
+                                '-loop']
+    print(" > " + " ".join(command))
+    server = subprocess.Popen(command, stdout=subprocess.PIPE, stderr=subprocess.STDOUT)
+    time.sleep(3)
+
+    # Find and return the port that the server is bound to.
+    server_conn = psutil.Process(server.pid).connections()[0]
+
+    # Run tests
+    yield server_conn.laddr.port
+
+    # Teardown: stop server
+    server.kill()
+
+@pytest.fixture(params=ossl_algorithms.signatures)
+def parametrized_sig_server(request, server_prog, server_type, test_artifacts_dir, worker_id):
+    sig_alg = request.param
+    if sig_alg not in bssl_algorithms.sig_to_code_point:
+        pytest.skip("{} is unsupported by OQS-BoringSSL.".format(sig_alg))
+
+    # Setup: start server
+    if server_type == "ossl":
+        helpers.gen_openssl_keys(server_prog, os.path.join('apps', 'openssl.cnf'), sig_alg, test_artifacts_dir, worker_id)
+        command = [server_prog, 's_server',
+                                '-cert', os.path.join(test_artifacts_dir, '{}_{}_srv.crt'.format(worker_id, sig_alg)),
+                                '-key', os.path.join(test_artifacts_dir, '{}_{}_srv.key'.format(worker_id, sig_alg)),
+                                '-tls1_3',
+                                '-quiet',
+                                '-accept', '0']
+    elif server_type == "bssl":
+        command = [server_prog, 'server',
+                                '-accept', '0',
+                                '-sig-alg', sig_alg,
+                                '-loop']
+    print(" > " + " ".join(command))
+    server = subprocess.Popen(command, stdout=subprocess.PIPE, stderr=subprocess.STDOUT)
+    time.sleep(3)
+
+    # Find and return the port that the server is bound to.
+    server_conn = psutil.Process(server.pid).connections()[0]
+
+    # Run tests
+    yield sig_alg, server_conn.laddr.port
+
+    # Teardown: stop server
+    server.kill()
+
+@pytest.mark.parametrize('kex_name', ossl_algorithms.key_exchanges)
+def test_kex(kex_name, test_artifacts_dir, sig_default_server_port, client_prog, client_type, worker_id):
+    if kex_name not in bssl_algorithms.kex_to_nid:
+        pytest.skip("{} is unsupported by OQS-BoringSSL.".format(kex_name))
+    if client_type == "ossl":
+        client_output = helpers.run_subprocess([client_prog, 's_client',
+                                                             '-groups', kex_name,
+                                                             '-connect', 'localhost:{}'.format(sig_default_server_port)],
+                                         input='Q'.encode())
+        if kex_name.startswith('p256'):
+            kex_full_name = "{} hybrid".format(kex_name)
+        else:
+            kex_full_name = kex_name
+        if not "Server Temp Key: {}".format(kex_full_name) in client_output:
+            print(client_output)
+            assert False, "Server temp key missing."
+    elif client_type == "bssl":
+        helpers.run_subprocess([client_prog, '-port', str(sig_default_server_port),
+                                             '-expect-version', 'TLSv1.3',
+                                             '-curves', bssl_algorithms.kex_to_nid[kex_name],
+                                             '-expect-curve-id', bssl_algorithms.kex_to_nid[kex_name],
+                                             '-expect-peer-signature-algorithm', bssl_algorithms.sig_to_code_point['oqs_sig_default'],
+                                             '-shim-shuts-down'])
+
+def test_sig(parametrized_sig_server, client_prog, client_type, worker_id):
+    server_sig = parametrized_sig_server[0]
+    server_port = parametrized_sig_server[1]
+
+
+    if client_type == "ossl":
+        client_output = helpers.run_subprocess([client_prog, 's_client',
+                                                             '-groups', 'oqs_kem_default',
comment.body: Why is (only) 'oqs_kem_default' hardcoded here? What's with the other KEMs?

comment.body: I've put it there since it is "auto-generated" [here](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssl/pull/198/files#diff-787e2ee4e783740c5416aa62b3fa49dfR21). The file is picked up from the BoringSSL source code to determine what algorithms BoringSSL supports.

comment.body: The `bssl server` program generates a self-signed cert as seen [here](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/boringssl/blob/master/tool/server.cc#L138). It also means I'm only generating self-signed certificates for these tests (as opposed to self-signed CA signing a server certificate).

comment.body: The idea behind the "basic" tests, is to test all KEMS with the signature set to `oqs_sig_default`, and then test all signatures with the KEM set to `oqs_kem_default`. Not every possible combination of KEM+Signature is tested here; that's done in `test_full.py`. I've the basic tests in the code, but not the CI, to make for a faster testing+development cycle before opening a PR.

comment.body: OK... for a BoringSSL<->BoringSSL connection test I'd understand that, but shouldn't a BoringSSL<->OpenSSL connection test (also) validate "each other's" persistent data structures (aka certs)? How otherwise do we check server auth of the implementations against each other? Or is that out of scope? That said, do we have a scope for this testing written up somewhere?

+    elif server_type == "bssl":
+        command = [server_prog, 'server',
+                                '-accept', '0',
+                                '-sig-alg', sig_alg,
+                                '-loop']
+    print(" > " + " ".join(command))
+    server = subprocess.Popen(command, stdout=subprocess.PIPE, stderr=subprocess.STDOUT)
+    time.sleep(3)
+
+    # Find and return the port that the server is bound to.
+    server_conn = psutil.Process(server.pid).connections()[0]
+
+    # Run tests
+    yield server_conn.laddr.port
+
+    # Teardown: stop server
+    server.kill()
+
+@pytest.fixture(params=ossl_algorithms.signatures)
+def parametrized_sig_server(request, server_prog, server_type, test_artifacts_dir, worker_id):
+    sig_alg = request.param
+    if sig_alg not in bssl_algorithms.sig_to_code_point:
+        pytest.skip("{} is unsupported by OQS-BoringSSL.".format(sig_alg))
+
+    # Setup: start server
+    if server_type == "ossl":
+        helpers.gen_openssl_keys(server_prog, os.path.join('apps', 'openssl.cnf'), sig_alg, test_artifacts_dir, worker_id)
+        command = [server_prog, 's_server',
+                                '-cert', os.path.join(test_artifacts_dir, '{}_{}_srv.crt'.format(worker_id, sig_alg)),
+                                '-key', os.path.join(test_artifacts_dir, '{}_{}_srv.key'.format(worker_id, sig_alg)),
+                                '-tls1_3',
+                                '-quiet',
+                                '-accept', '0']
+    elif server_type == "bssl":
+        command = [server_prog, 'server',
+                                '-accept', '0',
+                                '-sig-alg', sig_alg,
+                                '-loop']
+    print(" > " + " ".join(command))
+    server = subprocess.Popen(command, stdout=subprocess.PIPE, stderr=subprocess.STDOUT)
+    time.sleep(3)
+
+    # Find and return the port that the server is bound to.
+    server_conn = psutil.Process(server.pid).connections()[0]
+
+    # Run tests
+    yield sig_alg, server_conn.laddr.port
+
+    # Teardown: stop server
+    server.kill()
+
+@pytest.mark.parametrize('kex_name', ossl_algorithms.key_exchanges)
+def test_kex(kex_name, test_artifacts_dir, sig_default_server_port, client_prog, client_type, worker_id):
+    if kex_name not in bssl_algorithms.kex_to_nid:
+        pytest.skip("{} is unsupported by OQS-BoringSSL.".format(kex_name))
+    if client_type == "ossl":
+        client_output = helpers.run_subprocess([client_prog, 's_client',
+                                                             '-groups', kex_name,
+                                                             '-connect', 'localhost:{}'.format(sig_default_server_port)],
+                                         input='Q'.encode())
+        if kex_name.startswith('p256'):
+            kex_full_name = "{} hybrid".format(kex_name)
+        else:
+            kex_full_name = kex_name
+        if not "Server Temp Key: {}".format(kex_full_name) in client_output:
+            print(client_output)
+            assert False, "Server temp key missing."
+    elif client_type == "bssl":
+        helpers.run_subprocess([client_prog, '-port', str(sig_default_server_port),
+                                             '-expect-version', 'TLSv1.3',
+                                             '-curves', bssl_algorithms.kex_to_nid[kex_name],
+                                             '-expect-curve-id', bssl_algorithms.kex_to_nid[kex_name],
+                                             '-expect-peer-signature-algorithm', bssl_algorithms.sig_to_code_point['oqs_sig_default'],
+                                             '-shim-shuts-down'])
+
+def test_sig(parametrized_sig_server, client_prog, client_type, worker_id):
+    server_sig = parametrized_sig_server[0]
+    server_port = parametrized_sig_server[1]
+
+
+    if client_type == "ossl":
+        client_output = helpers.run_subprocess([client_prog, 's_client',
+                                                             '-groups', 'oqs_kem_default',
comment.body: Understood. Makes sense. Whatever remains of this in the code, I'd suggest to document in a README.md for interop tests.

pull_request.title: Added BoringSSL interoperability tests.
pull_request.body:
I've also added a new CircleCI job for BoringSSL interop-testing. Presently it's not a nightly-only job, but I'll change it to be nightly-only once the PR is approved.

I also haven't added a README for these tests, since I'm considering breaking them out into a separate "interoperability testing" repository once we're done with this release cycle.

+import ossl_algorithms

+@pytest.fixture()
+def sig_default_server_port(server_prog, server_type, test_artifacts_dir, worker_id):
+    # Setup: start server
+    sig_alg = "oqs_sig_default"
+    if server_type == "ossl":
+        helpers.gen_openssl_keys(server_prog, os.path.join('apps', 'openssl.cnf'), sig_alg, test_artifacts_dir, worker_id)
+        command = [server_prog, 's_server',
+                                '-cert', os.path.join(test_artifacts_dir, '{}_{}_srv.crt'.format(worker_id, sig_alg)),
+                                '-key', os.path.join(test_artifacts_dir, '{}_{}_srv.key'.format(worker_id, sig_alg)),
+                                '-tls1_3',

+        command = [server_prog, 'server',

+                                '-sig-alg', sig_alg,

comment.body:
The scope hasn't been written anywhere, but I'll add it to a README in this directory. The objective (I assume) is to test simply whether OQS-BoringSSL can process OQS-OpenSSL certificates and vice versa.

The `expect-peer-signature-algorithm` and `-expect-peer-cert-file` options [here](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssl/blob/interop-tests/oqs-interop-test/test_basic.py#L96) do just that. I'll look into whether I can use similar options with OpenSSL.

pull_request.title: Added BoringSSL interoperability tests.
pull_request.body:
I've also added a new CircleCI job for BoringSSL interop-testing. Presently it's not a nightly-only job, but I'll change it to be nightly-only once the PR is approved.

I also haven't added a README for these tests, since I'm considering breaking them out into a separate "interoperability testing" repository once we're done with this release cycle.
